include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:

CCI Rule 400.4111 Job description
• (1) An institution shall provide a job description
for each staff position that identifies rules,
required qualifications, and lines of authority.
Two of twelve employees' files reviewed was missing a job description that
identifies rules, required qualifications and lines of authority.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
• (i) Documentation from the Michigan
department of human services, the
equivalent state or Canadian provincial
agency, or equivalent agency in the
country where the person usually resides,
that the person has not been determined
to be a perpetrator of child abuse or child
neglect. The documentation shall be
completed not more than 30 days prior to
the start of employment and every 12
months thereafter.
One out of twelve employee files, completed a central registry clearance more
then 30 days prior to starting employment.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• The agency did not request or require technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:

• I recommended the need for incident reports to identify what de-escalation
techniques were used by staff prior to a restraint, the name of the restraint and
protective technique(s) used and the debriefing that occurred after a restraint. I
recommended adding prompts to staff written statements to generate more
information about what led to the incident and how staff responded.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
A change application was received requesting to decrease the agency’s overall
capacity from 60 youth to 30 youth and the agency will utilize three cottages for this
license.
Maltreatment in Care
There were 3 substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. Special Investigation 2023C000726SI dated 08/29/2023 which found staff
pushed youth to the ground. A correction action plan dated 10/09/2023 was
approved that noted staff involved was terminated and remaining staff members
will be trained. Special investigation 2024C00001086 dated 01/24/2024 which
found staff threw a shoe at a youth. A correction action plan dated 03/20/2024
was approved and noted staff involved was terminated and remaining staff
members will be trained. Special Investigation 2024SIC0001199 dated 02/27/2024
which found during an altercation staff hit a youth. A correction action plan dated
05/20/2024 was approved noted staff involved was terminated and remaining staff
members will be trained.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency submitted 6 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The non-compliance noted included staff not following policy and procedures
regarding appropriate behavior intervention and prohibited forms of interventions,
staff performing improper restraints, critical incident documentation and reporting,
and staff not following policy and procedures regarding appropriate response and
inappropriate threatening behaviors. A review of the CAP during this inspection
found the facility is in compliance with all their CAPs.
Financial Overview
There are no concerns identified based on a review of the facility’s budget and
financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable

Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator Assessment was done on time and was comprehensive and
reviewed the areas of noncompliance from the previous licensing review. There
were no citations from the interim inspection in 2023 cited as repeat citations in
this renewal inspection. The facility is continually assessing methods to better
support staff and ensure staff have the tools and trainings to provide care and
supervision for the youths.
Staff and Youth Interviews
I interviewed staff, who reported feeling supported by management, participating in
training, and having the training and tools to provide for the care and supervision
they need.
I interviewed youths who reported feeling safe, receiving therapy, enough food,
medication, and all their needs are being met. Youths reported having good
relationships with staff and expressed no concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An on-site inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on 06/27/2024. The
facility was found to be clean, neat, and appropriate. There were no issues of
concerns noted.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
